Opposition politics, in and of itself, does not necessarily lead to instability and social crisis. In fact, a healthy opposition can be beneficial for democracy, as it provides a necessary check and balance on those in power and ensures that diverse perspectives are represented.

However, there are certain circumstances in which opposition politics can lead to instability and social crisis. These include:

1. Polarization: When political differences become so extreme that people on opposite sides of the political spectrum are unable or unwilling to work together, it can lead to polarization and gridlock. This can make it difficult to pass important legislation or make decisions, which can lead to instability.
2. Demonization of opponents: When politicians and their supporters demonize those on the other side of the political divide, it can lead to heightened emotions and a sense of us-vs-them mentality. This can lead to social unrest and even violence.
3. Lack of trust: When the opposition party or politicians are seen as untrustworthy or illegitimate by large segments of the population, it can erode faith in the political system as a whole. This can lead to social unrest, as people become frustrated with the political process and feel that their voices are not being heard.
4. Political power struggles: When opposition parties or politicians feel that they have been unfairly excluded from power or that the ruling party is not following the rules of the game, it can lead to political power struggles. This can lead to instability and even violence, as both sides jockey for control.

In summary, opposition politics can lead to instability and social crisis in certain circumstances, particularly when there is polarization, demonization of opponents, lack of trust, and political power struggles. However, a healthy opposition is essential for democracy and can provide important checks and balances on those in power.
